dialogues.VERGER:
[1]Aren't they beautiful, Miss Starling... 
[2]Well, now, you see, one of them's hurt. And what will make it better?  Love. Isn't that odd. He think's he's hurt his knee--but the assurance, the assurance, the assurance that someone cares Suggests the hurt was elsewhere. 
[3]For the worst hurt, of course, that which will not heal, is the conviction no one cares. 
[4]Ah, yes, ah yes.  Our Doctor Lechter... And have they sent you, once again to capture him?  How terrible for you... 
[5]Because we must leave the past in the past. Ah.  And here we have artifacts of, yes, my own encounter with him... 
[6]No, no.  That's alright.  Yes.  Lechter's drawings of me.  Before... and, of course, after... Now:  you are not sent to pursue him.  Then your visit baffles me. 
[7]Because? 
[8]And why would you suspect me, of this ghoulishness? 
[9]Large resources, Starling, which I prefer to devote elsewhere.... 
[10]My encounter. 
[11]Yes, but we know who it was, and I will tell you, Agent Starling, what you know to be true.  I offered the bounty.  It was illegal, and, worse, it was wrong. And I thank God every day that I did not compound my sinful life by the stain of a murder.  Do you  Agent Starling:  do you know God? 
[12]Isn't it funny?  You can look on my face  which you would grant me, is the most hideous sight you will see in what I hope is a long life. You can look at me.  Which shows a Strength which must come from strong strong convictions. But you shy when I say the name of God. 
[13]I have not, I would not.  For life life goes on Starling.  And, wait, wait, I wish to talk to you... I'm...   (TO THE NURSE, WHO IS TAKING STARLING'S ARM) One moment.  I was afflicted, do you see, but my affliction was not in my meeting with your Dr. Lechter.  I was afflicted before. Before.  Do you see?  In my arrogance. Do not  Do not curse God when you are humiliated.  Listen to me: embrace it, and you embrace life.... Listen, and you hear the word of God... 
[14]Are you Franklin ? 
[15]Where do you live? 
[16]In and out.  Yes.  And Mama... and Mama, is not your real Mama, is she Franklin? 
[17]She's not the first foster that you've had.  Is she? 
[18]Do you like it at your home, Franklin? 
[19]Yes.... yes... 
[20]Yes.  Franklin, you can't live there anymore.  With Mama and Shirly and Kittykat.  You have to go away. 
[21]The government says.  Mama has lost her job, so she can't be your foster mother.  The police found a marijuana cigarette in your home.  You can't see Mama anymore.  Or Shirley.  Or Kitty Cat.  That's what the Government says... 
[22]...or perhaps they just don't want you anymore.  Could that be?  And, do you know what will happen to Kitty Cat?  When you go away.  The police will take her, and they'll give her a shot.  With a shiny needle.  They'll give Kitty Cat a shot.  And it will hurt her.  And then she will die. 
[23]Come here...

[36]It's time to step up the pressure on our Sweet Miss Starling.  ...call our friend at the F.B.I.  And, instead of finding Lechter, let's help Him find us.

dialogues.FELL:
[1]Of course, Commendatore... 
[2]I never met him.  I knew him only from his writings. 
[3]...yes. 
[4]It is only temporary, until my confirmation by...

[7]If your duty requires it.

[9]Yes, it must be hard to be a policeman. Is it hard?  Must one, then, be constantly suspicious? 
[10]I saw a man in disheveled clothing, but clean.  Just dressed--in the middle of the... 
[11]I saw a man, somewhat fatigued. Quickly dressed, a bit dishevelled.  In the middle of the day. An old story.  And then I saw the clothing was fresh--therefore:  a man who dressed at home.  And then I remarked the new wedding ring.  And so:  the story gave me pause.  A lovely story.  A new, and a beloved wife.  I wish you joy. 
[12]I'm a historian.  It is our task to assemble the seemingly unconnected into the obvious. 
[13]My scar is a war-wound. 
[14]Carpal-tunnel syndrome.  From a life of typing.  Commendatore.  History, a hazardous profession.

[16]You resemble a figure from the Della Robia Rondels, in your family's chapel at Santa Croce. 
[17]I have had the honor. 
[18]I wondered that an officer of your exalted rank should come, so late, into the case. 
[19]I wonder no longer.  You were out of the country. 
[20]I sense... The faintest whiff of a perfume, whose base, whose base, whose base is "Hamamelis" ... it is witch-hazel--such a clean scent.  No, not a European scent. I would say it is a scent of the New World.  I would say, you have been in America.  Have I struck home? 
[21]...you have brought this perfume... brought this perfume.  Back.  Back from America.  To your New Wife... 
[22]You will be the first I call. 
[23]Commendatore would you do me the honor of introducing me. 
[24]Enchante. 
[25]Sadly, no.  And I find that birth is one of the few things in life which study and a pleasant attitude can not amend. What do you think? 
[26]Indeed I am.  And the connection, between Dante, and, in fact, between your illustrious forebears... if you'd come with me, I could show you... 
[27]How unfortunate. 
[28]May I...? 
[29]What a lovely perfume.  I believe I recognize it, do I not...? 
[30]A wonderful country... 
[31]I have had many excellent meals there. 
[32]...should love to correct your error. 
[33]Well, if you will excuse me.  Madame. What a pleasure.

[35]If such there breathe, I'm sure you could unearth him... Your reputation does you honor. 
[36]Take mine.

[39]
[40]...how so?

[44]Yes, quite...

[46]...where shall we eat.  And what shall we eat. 
[47]Della vigna was disgraced and blinded for his betrayal of his emperor's trust- -through avarice.  Avarice and hanging are linked in the ancient and the madeadeval mind. 
[48]Judas and Pier Della Vigna are linked in Dante by the avarice he saw in them, and their subsequent deaths by hanging.  Ah Commendatore Pazzi...

[60]On a related subject Signor Pazzi, I must confess to you:  I'm giving serious thought to eating your wife. 
[61]Yes.  Your Wife.  Laura.  L'Orange, which is the topnote of her skin, wouldn't you say?  Or do I grow too personal?  but that is what I think of, when I think of her.  And how could I but think of her? I haven't had a bit all day.  The kidney and the liver would be su1table for a dinner tonight.  But the rest of the meat should hang for a week, in these cool conditions.  Wouldn't you say?  Nod once for yes. If you tell me what I need to know, then it would be convenient for me to leave without my meal.  And Mrs. Pazzi will remain unscathed.  I'll out the questions to you, and we'll see:  I saw at the theatre you had betrayed me. And, when the police didn't come, it was clear you had sold me out.  Was it to Mason Verger? dialogues.GUIDE:

dialogues.RICCI:
[1]Ah, Pazzi.  How was America...? 
[2]We may need you to stop bloodshed. 
[3]They're grilling the applicant for the Vacant Post.

dialogues.SOGLIATO:
[1]Now:  our applicant holds in his hand, in his Non-Italian-Hand, a note, from Dante Aligheri himself.  Would he recognize it, I think not... 
[2]Indeed I do.  Because he is my Nephew? No.  Because he.... 
[3]Yes, fine, of course he can read the note.  His Italian is admirable, for a straniero.  But is he familiar with... 
[4]The personalities of pre-Renaissance Florence?  I think not. 
[5]What if he came upon a note in, the Capponi Library, this great Italian Institution, which he now graces us with his bid to Direct, a note from Guido de Cavalcanti.  Would he recognize it, I think not. 
[6]Would you care to address that, Dr. Fell...? 
[7]...why do you want this job?
dialogues.SUPERIOR:
[1]And what does that mean? 
[2]"A liaison position with the Opera." 
[3]Rinaldo, what happened to you? You want me to reach out for tickets to the Opera.  Say so.  What is that young girl doing to you...? 
[4]She must be something special After Dark. 
[5]Thirty thousand dollars reward.  In the whereabouts of Il Dottore Fanelli, or the apprehension of his... 
[6]The short term problem is the tickets-- The long-term problem is your wife. 
[7]And the related problem is your job. Aha.  And here it all comes together.  To get a promotion you must keep your job.  To keep your job you must solve this case.  Solve the case, and the reward may help you keep your wife.  In short, the solution to all your problems lies in This File:  The Disappearance of Il Dottore Fanelli.
